title: Article 1: Name and territory of the Union
text: Article 1 of the Constitution of India states: India, that is Bharat, shall be a Union of States. This article is part of the Indian Constitution and falls under constitutional law.

title: Article 2: Admission or establishment of new States
text: Article 2 of the Constitution of India states: Parliament may admit new States into the Union. This article is part of the Indian Constitution and falls under constitutional law.

title: Article 3: Formation of new States
text: Article 3 of the Constitution of India states: Parliament may form new States by separation or merger. This article is part of the Indian Constitution and falls under constitutional law.

title: Article 4: Laws made under Articles 2 and 3
text: Article 4 of the Constitution of India states: Such laws shall not be deemed amendments. This article is part of the Indian Constitution and falls under constitutional law.

title: Article 5: Citizenship at commencement
text: Article 5 of the Constitution of India states: Persons domiciled in India at commencement. This article is part of the Indian Constitution and falls under constitutional law.

title: Article 6: Rights of citizenship
text: Article 6 of the Constitution of India states: Rights of persons migrating to India from Pakistan. This article is part of the Indian Constitution and falls under constitutional law.

title: Article 7: Rights of migrants
text: Article 7 of the Constitution of India states: Rights of persons migrating to Pakistan. This article is part of the Indian Constitution and falls under constitutional law.

title: Article 8: Rights of overseas citizens
text: Article 8 of the Constitution of India states: Rights of persons of Indian origin residing abroad. This article is part of the Indian Constitution and falls under constitutional law.

title: Article 9: Persons voluntarily acquiring foreign citizenship
text: Article 9 of the Constitution of India states: Cease to be Indian citizens. This article is part of the Indian Constitution and falls under constitutional law.

title: Article 10: Continuance of citizenship
text: Article 10 of the Constitution of India states: Every person continues as citizen subject to provisions. This article is part of the Indian Constitution and falls under constitutional law.

title: Article 11: Parliament to regulate citizenship
text: Article 11 of the Constitution of India states: Parliament may make laws regarding citizenship. This article is part of the Indian Constitution and falls under constitutional law.

title: Article 12: Definition of State
text: Article 12 of the Constitution of India states: State includes Government and Parliament, Legislature, and all local authorities. This article is part of the Indian Constitution and falls under fundamental rights.

title: Article 13: Laws inconsistent with FR void
text: Article 13 of the Constitution of India states: Laws inconsistent with Fundamental Rights shall be void. This article is part of the Indian Constitution and falls under fundamental rights.

title: Article 14: Equality before law
text: Article 14 of the Constitution of India states: The State shall not deny equality before law or equal protection of laws. This article is part of the Indian Constitution and falls under fundamental rights.

title: Article 15: Prohibition of discrimination
text: Article 15 of the Constitution of India states: Prohibition on grounds of religion, race, caste, sex or place of birth. This article is part of the Indian Constitution and falls under fundamental rights.

title: Article 16: Equality of opportunity
text: Article 16 of the Constitution of India states: Equality of opportunity in matters of public employment. This article is part of the Indian Constitution and falls under fundamental rights.

title: Article 17: Abolition of untouchability
text: Article 17 of the Constitution of India states: Untouchability is abolished and its practice is forbidden. This article is part of the Indian Constitution and falls under fundamental rights.

title: Article 18: Abolition of titles
text: Article 18 of the Constitution of India states: No titles except military and academic distinctions. This article is part of the Indian Constitution and falls under fundamental rights.

title: Article 19: Protection of six rights
text: Article 19 of the Constitution of India states: Right to freedom of speech, assembly, association, movement, residence, and profession. This article is part of the Indian Constitution and falls under fundamental rights.

text: Article 20 of the Constitution of India states: Protection in respect of conviction for offenses. This article is part of the Indian Constitution and falls under fundamental rights.

text: Article 21 of the Constitution of India states: No person shall be deprived of life or personal liberty except by procedure established by law. This article is part of the Indian Constitution and falls under fundamental rights.

title: Article 21A: Right to education
text: Article 21A of the Constitution of India states: Free and compulsory education for children 6-14 years. This article is part of the Indian Constitution and falls under fundamental rights.

title: Article 22: Protection against arrest
text: Article 22 of the Constitution of India states: Protection against arrest and detention in certain cases. This article is part of the Indian Constitution and falls under fundamental rights.

text: Section 151 of the Civil Procedure Code, 1908 deals with Saving of inherent powers of Court. This section is crucial for civil proceedings and litigation in India.

title: Evidence Act Section 3: Evidence
text: Section 3 of the Indian Evidence Act, 1872 states: Evidence means statements which court permits or requires to be made before it. This is a fundamental provision in the law of evidence in India.

title: Evidence Act Section 5: Evidence may be given
text: Section 5 of the Indian Evidence Act, 1872 states: Evidence may be given of facts in issue and relevant facts. This is a fundamental provision in the law of evidence in India.

title: Evidence Act Section 6: Relevancy of facts
text: Section 6 of the Indian Evidence Act, 1872 states: Facts forming part of same transaction are relevant. This is a fundamental provision in the law of evidence in India.

title: Evidence Act Section 8: Motive, preparation and conduct
text: Section 8 of the Indian Evidence Act, 1872 states: Motive, preparation and previous or subsequent conduct relevant. This is a fundamental provision in the law of evidence in India.

title: Evidence Act Section 11: Facts inconsistent with fact in issue
text: Section 11 of the Indian Evidence Act, 1872 states: Facts inconsistent with fact in issue are relevant. This is a fundamental provision in the law of evidence in India.

title: Evidence Act Section 14: Facts showing system
text: Section 14 of the Indian Evidence Act, 1872 states: Facts showing existence of state of mind or body are relevant. This is a fundamental provision in the law of evidence in India.

title: Evidence Act Section 17: Admission
text: Section 17 of the Indian Evidence Act, 1872 states: Admission is statement suggesting inference as to fact in issue. This is a fundamental provision in the law of evidence in India.

title: Evidence Act Section 21: Admissions by parties
text: Section 21 of the Indian Evidence Act, 1872 states: Admission by party or his agent. This is a fundamental provision in the law of evidence in India.

title: Evidence Act Section 22: Oral admissions
text: Section 22 of the Indian Evidence Act, 1872 states: Oral admissions as to contents of documents are not relevant. This is a fundamental provision in the law of evidence in India.

title: Evidence Act Section 24: Confession caused by inducement
text: Section 24 of the Indian Evidence Act, 1872 states: Confession caused by inducement, threat or promise is irrelevant. This is a fundamental provision in the law of evidence in India.

title: Evidence Act Section 25: Confession to police officer
text: Section 25 of the Indian Evidence Act, 1872 states: Confession to police officer not to be proved. This is a fundamental provision in the law of evidence in India.

title: Evidence Act Section 26: Confession in custody
text: Section 26 of the Indian Evidence Act, 1872 states: Confession by accused while in custody not relevant unless made in immediate presence of Magistrate. This is a fundamental provision in the law of evidence in India.

title: Evidence Act Section 27: Information received from accused
text: Section 27 of the Indian Evidence Act, 1872 states: How much information received from accused may be proved. This is a fundamental provision in the law of evidence in India.

title: Evidence Act Section 32: Cases in which hearsay allowed
text: Section 32 of the Indian Evidence Act, 1872 states: Cases in which statement of relevant fact by person who is dead is relevant. This is a fundamental provision in the law of evidence in India.

title: Evidence Act Section 45: Opinion of experts
text: Section 45 of the Indian Evidence Act, 1872 states: Opinion of experts is relevant. This is a fundamental provision in the law of evidence in India.

title: Evidence Act Section 60: Oral evidence must be direct
text: Section 60 of the Indian Evidence Act, 1872 states: Oral evidence must be direct. This is a fundamental provision in the law of evidence in India.

title: Evidence Act Section 65: Proof of electronic records
text: Section 65 of the Indian Evidence Act, 1872 states: Cases in which secondary evidence relating to electronic record may be given. This is a fundamental provision in the law of evidence in India.

title: Evidence Act Section 65A: Special provisions for computer output
text: Section 65A of the Indian Evidence Act, 1872 states: Special provisions as to evidence relating to electronic record. This is a fundamental provision in the law of evidence in India.

title: Evidence Act Section 65B: Admissibility of electronic records
text: Section 65B of the Indian Evidence Act, 1872 states: Admissibility of electronic records. This is a fundamental provision in the law of evidence in India.

title: Evidence Act Section 91: Best evidence rule
text: Section 91 of the Indian Evidence Act, 1872 states: Evidence of terms of contracts, grants and other dispositions of property reduced to writing. This is a fundamental provision in the law of evidence in India.

title: Evidence Act Section 101: Burden of proof
text: Section 101 of the Indian Evidence Act, 1872 states: Burden of proof lies on person who asserts. This is a fundamental provision in the law of evidence in India.

title: Evidence Act Section 102: Burden of proof in criminal cases
text: Section 102 of the Indian Evidence Act, 1872 states: Burden of proof on accused. This is a fundamental provision in the law of evidence in India.

title: Evidence Act Section 103: Burden of proof as to particular fact
text: Section 103 of the Indian Evidence Act, 1872 states: Burden of proving particular fact on person desiring court to believe it. This is a fundamental provision in the law of evidence in India.

title: Evidence Act Section 104: Burden of proving that case comes under exception
text: Section 104 of the Indian Evidence Act, 1872 states: Burden of proving fact to be proved to make evidence admissible. This is a fundamental provision in the law of evidence in India.

title: Evidence Act Section 105: Burden of proving exception
text: Section 105 of the Indian Evidence Act, 1872 states: Burden of proving that case of accused comes within exceptions. This is a fundamental provision in the law of evidence in India.

title: Evidence Act Section 106: Burden of proving fact especially within knowledge
text: Section 106 of the Indian Evidence Act, 1872 states: Burden of proving fact especially within knowledge. This is a fundamental provision in the law of evidence in India.

title: Evidence Act Section 107: Burden of proving death
text: Section 107 of the Indian Evidence Act, 1872 states: Burden of proving death of person known to have been alive within 30 years. This is a fundamental provision in the law of evidence in India.

title: Evidence Act Section 108: Burden of proving that person is alive
text: Section 108 of the Indian Evidence Act, 1872 states: Burden of proving that person is alive who has not been heard of for 7 years. This is a fundamental provision in the law of evidence in India.

title: Evidence Act Section 111: Proof of good faith
text: Section 111 of the Indian Evidence Act, 1872 states: Proof of good faith in transactions where one party is in relation of active confidence. This is a fundamental provision in the law of evidence in India.

title: Evidence Act Section 112: Birth during marriage
text: Section 112 of the Indian Evidence Act, 1872 states: Presumption as to legitimacy - birth during marriage is conclusive proof. This is a fundamental provision in the law of evidence in India.

title: Evidence Act Section 113A: Presumption as to abetment of suicide by married woman
text: Section 113A of the Indian Evidence Act, 1872 states: Presumption as to abetment of suicide by married woman. This is a fundamental provision in the law of evidence in India.

title: Evidence Act Section 113B: Presumption as to dowry death
text: Section 113B of the Indian Evidence Act, 1872 states: Presumption as to dowry death. This is a fundamental provision in the law of evidence in India.

title: Evidence Act Section 114: Court may presume existence of fact
text: Section 114 of the Indian Evidence Act, 1872 states: Court may presume existence of certain facts. This is a fundamental provision in the law of evidence in India.

title: Evidence Act Section 118: Who may testify
text: Section 118 of the Indian Evidence Act, 1872 states: All persons shall be competent to testify unless court considers they are prevented from understanding questions or giving rational answers. This is a fundamental provision in the law of evidence in India.

title: Evidence Act Section 120: Presumption about genuineness of certified copies
text: Section 120 of the Indian Evidence Act, 1872 states: Presumption as to documents produced as record of evidence. This is a fundamental provision in the law of evidence in India.

title: Evidence Act Section 122: Privilege from disclosure - marital communications
text: Section 122 of the Indian Evidence Act, 1872 states: Communications during marriage. This is a fundamental provision in the law of evidence in India.

title: Evidence Act Section 123: Privilege - official unpublished documents
text: Section 123 of the Indian Evidence Act, 1872 states: Evidence as to affairs of State. This is a fundamental provision in the law of evidence in India.

title: Evidence Act Section 126: Professional privilege - legal advisers
text: Section 126 of the Indian Evidence Act, 1872 states: No barrister, attorney, pleader or vakil shall be permitted to disclose any communication made to him. This is a fundamental provision in the law of evidence in India.

title: Evidence Act Section 129: Production of title deeds
text: Section 129 of the Indian Evidence Act, 1872 states: What evidence to be given when statement forms part of conversation. This is a fundamental provision in the law of evidence in India.

title: Evidence Act Section 131: Witness production
text: Section 131 of the Indian Evidence Act, 1872 states: Production of documents or electronic records which another person has legal obligation to produce. This is a fundamental provision in the law of evidence in India.

title: Evidence Act Section 137: Examination in chief
text: Section 137 of the Indian Evidence Act, 1872 states: Examination-in-chief, cross-examination and re-examination. This is a fundamental provision in the law of evidence in India.

title: Evidence Act Section 138: Order of examination
text: Section 138 of the Indian Evidence Act, 1872 states: Order of production and examination of witnesses. This is a fundamental provision in the law of evidence in India.

title: Evidence Act Section 145: Cross-examination
text: Section 145 of the Indian Evidence Act, 1872 states: Cross-examination as to previous statements in writing. This is a fundamental provision in the law of evidence in India.

title: Evidence Act Section 146: Questions to test veracity
text: Section 146 of the Indian Evidence Act, 1872 states: Questions lawful in cross-examination. This is a fundamental provision in the law of evidence in India.

title: Evidence Act Section 148: Witnesses to character
text: Section 148 of the Indian Evidence Act, 1872 states: Questions on cross-examination as to character and credit. This is a fundamental provision in the law of evidence in India.

title: Evidence Act Section 151: Impeaching credit
text: Section 151 of the Indian Evidence Act, 1872 states: Questions to test credit of witness. This is a fundamental provision in the law of evidence in India.

title: Evidence Act Section 153: Hostile witness
text: Section 153 of the Indian Evidence Act, 1872 states: Indecent and scandalous questions. This is a fundamental provision in the law of evidence in India.

title: Evidence Act Section 154: Questions tending to criminate
text: Section 154 of the Indian Evidence Act, 1872 states: Question by party to his own witness. This is a fundamental provision in the law of evidence in India.

title: Evidence Act Section 155: Impeaching credit
text: Section 155 of the Indian Evidence Act, 1872 states: Impeaching credit of witness. This is a fundamental provision in the law of evidence in India.

title: Evidence Act Section 157: Former statements
text: Section 157 of the Indian Evidence Act, 1872 states: Former statements of witness may be proved to corroborate later testimony. This is a fundamental provision in the law of evidence in India.

title: Evidence Act Section 160: Refresh memory
text: Section 160 of the Indian Evidence Act, 1872 states: Witness using document to refresh memory. This is a fundamental provision in the law of evidence in India.

title: Evidence Act Section 162: Production of documents
text: Section 162 of the Indian Evidence Act, 1872 states: Production of documents. This is a fundamental provision in the law of evidence in India.

title: Evidence Act Section 165: Judge's power to put questions
text: Section 165 of the Indian Evidence Act, 1872 states: Judge's power to put questions or order production. This is a fundamental provision in the law of evidence in India.

title: Contract Act Section 2: Definitions
text: Section 2 of the Indian Contract Act, 1872 states: Definitions of proposal, promise, consideration, agreement, contract, void agreement, voidable contract, void contract. This is an essential provision in contract law in India.

title: Contract Act Section 10: Agreement must be contract
text: Section 10 of the Indian Contract Act, 1872 states: What agreements are contracts - free consent, competency, lawful consideration and object. This is an essential provision in contract law in India.

title: Contract Act Section 11: Who are competent
text: Section 11 of the Indian Contract Act, 1872 states: Who are competent to contract - age of majority, sound mind, not disqualified by law. This is an essential provision in contract law in India.

title: Contract Act Section 13: Consent definition
text: Section 13 of the Indian Contract Act, 1872 states: Consent is said to be free when not caused by coercion, undue influence, fraud, misrepresentation or mistake. This is an essential provision in contract law in India.

title: Contract Act Section 14: Free consent
text: Section 14 of the Indian Contract Act, 1872 states: Consent is free when not caused by coercion, undue influence, fraud, misrepresentation or mistake. This is an essential provision in contract law in India.

title: Contract Act Section 15: Coercion
text: Section 15 of the Indian Contract Act, 1872 states: Coercion is committing or threatening to commit any act forbidden by IPC or unlawfully detaining property. This is an essential provision in contract law in India.

title: Contract Act Section 16: Undue influence
text: Section 16 of the Indian Contract Act, 1872 states: Contract is induced by undue influence when relations are such that one party is in position to dominate will of other. This is an essential provision in contract law in India.

title: Contract Act Section 17: Fraud
text: Section 17 of the Indian Contract Act, 1872 states: Fraud means suggestion of fact which is not true by one who does not believe it to be true. This is an essential provision in contract law in India.

title: Contract Act Section 18: Misrepresentation
text: Section 18 of the Indian Contract Act, 1872 states: Misrepresentation means positive assertion in a manner not warranted by information of person making it. This is an essential provision in contract law in India.

title: Contract Act Section 19: Voidability of agreements
text: Section 19 of the Indian Contract Act, 1872 states: When consent to agreement is caused by coercion, fraud or misrepresentation, agreement is voidable. This is an essential provision in contract law in India.

title: Contract Act Section 20: Agreement void where both parties under mistake
text: Section 20 of the Indian Contract Act, 1872 states: Where both parties under mistake as to matter of fact essential to agreement, agreement is void. This is an essential provision in contract law in India.

title: Contract Act Section 23: Unlawful consideration or object
text: Section 23 of the Indian Contract Act, 1872 states: Consideration or object is unlawful if forbidden by law, defeats provisions of law, is fraudulent, involves injury to person or property, or is immoral or opposed to public policy. This is an essential provision in contract law in India.

title: Contract Act Section 24: Agreement without consideration void
text: Section 24 of the Indian Contract Act, 1872 states: Agreement without consideration is void unless it is in writing and registered, promise to compensate for past voluntary service, or promise to pay time-barred debt. This is an essential provision in contract law in India.

title: Contract Act Section 25: Exceptions to s.24
text: Section 25 of the Indian Contract Act, 1872 states: Agreement without consideration is void except promises made out of natural love and affection, voluntary service, or time-barred debt. This is an essential provision in contract law in India.

title: Contract Act Section 26: Agreement in restraint of marriage void
text: Section 26 of the Indian Contract Act, 1872 states: Agreement in restraint of marriage of any person other than minor is void. This is an essential provision in contract law in India.

title: Contract Act Section 27: Agreement in restraint of trade void
text: Section 27 of the Indian Contract Act, 1872 states: Agreement in restraint of trade is void. This is an essential provision in contract law in India.

title: Contract Act Section 28: Agreement in restraint of legal proceedings void
text: Section 28 of the Indian Contract Act, 1872 states: Agreement in restraint of legal proceedings is void. This is an essential provision in contract law in India.

title: Contract Act Section 29: Agreements void for uncertainty
text: Section 29 of the Indian Contract Act, 1872 states: Agreements void for uncertainty or wagering. This is an essential provision in contract law in India.

title: Contract Act Section 30: Wagering agreements void
text: Section 30 of the Indian Contract Act, 1872 states: Agreements by way of wager are void. This is an essential provision in contract law in India.

title: Contract Act Section 36: Obligations arising
text: Section 36 of the Indian Contract Act, 1872 states: Obligations of parties to contract must be performed unless dispensed with or altered by parties or by law. This is an essential provision in contract law in India.

title: Contract Act Section 37: Obligation of parties
text: Section 37 of the Indian Contract Act, 1872 states: Parties to contract must either perform or offer to perform their respective promises. This is an essential provision in contract law in India.

title: Contract Act Section 39: Performance by party not at fault
text: Section 39 of the Indian Contract Act, 1872 states: When party to contract has refused to perform or disabled himself from performing promise in its entirety, promisee may put an end to contract. This is an essential provision in contract law in India.

title: Contract Act Section 40: Person by whom promise is to be performed
text: Section 40 of the Indian Contract Act, 1872 states: If contract requires performance of promise by promisor, he must perform or offer to perform it himself. This is an essential provision in contract law in India.

title: Contract Act Section 51: Mode of communication
text: Section 51 of the Indian Contract Act, 1872 states: Mode of communication, acceptance and revocation of proposals. This is an essential provision in contract law in India.

title: Contract Act Section 53: Liability of joint promisors
text: Section 53 of the Indian Contract Act, 1872 states: Joint promisors may be compelled to perform jointly or separately. This is an essential provision in contract law in India.

title: Contract Act Section 54: Rights of joint promisee
text: Section 54 of the Indian Contract Act, 1872 states: Where promisee accepts performance from one of several joint promisors, he cannot afterwards proceed against other joint promisors. This is an essential provision in contract law in India.

title: Contract Act Section 55: Effect of failure to perform
text: Section 55 of the Indian Contract Act, 1872 states: Effect of failure to perform at fixed time in contract in which time is essence. This is an essential provision in contract law in India.

title: Contract Act Section 56: Impossibility of performance
text: Section 56 of the Indian Contract Act, 1872 states: Agreement to do impossible act is void. This is an essential provision in contract law in India.

title: Contract Act Section 62: Novation
text: Section 62 of the Indian Contract Act, 1872 states: Novation, rescission and alteration of contract. This is an essential provision in contract law in India.

title: Contract Act Section 63: Waiver
text: Section 63 of the Indian Contract Act, 1872 states: Promise may dispense with or remit performance of promise. This is an essential provision in contract law in India.

title: Contract Act Section 64: Consequences of rescission
text: Section 64 of the Indian Contract Act, 1872 states: Consequences of rescission of voidable contract. This is an essential provision in contract law in India.

title: Contract Act Section 65: Restitution
text: Section 65 of the Indian Contract Act, 1872 states: Obligation to restore benefits received under void or voidable contract. This is an essential provision in contract law in India.

title: Contract Act Section 70: Obligation to pay for non-gratuitous acts
text: Section 70 of the Indian Contract Act, 1872 states: Person enjoying benefit of non-gratuitous act must compensate. This is an essential provision in contract law in India.

title: Contract Act Section 73: Compensation for loss
text: Section 73 of the Indian Contract Act, 1872 states: Compensation for loss or damage caused by breach of contract. This is an essential provision in contract law in India.

title: Contract Act Section 74: Liquidated damages
text: Section 74 of the Indian Contract Act, 1872 states: Compensation for breach of contract where sum named or penalty stipulated. This is an essential provision in contract law in India.

title: Contract Act Section 75: Compensation on anticipatory breach
text: Section 75 of the Indian Contract Act, 1872 states: Party rightfully rescinding contract entitled to compensation for any loss. This is an essential provision in contract law in India.

title: Contract Act Section 124: Contract of indemnity
text: Section 124 of the Indian Contract Act, 1872 states: Contract by which one party promises to save other from loss caused to him by conduct of promisor or any other person. This is an essential provision in contract law in India.

title: Contract Act Section 126: Contract of guarantee
text: Section 126 of the Indian Contract Act, 1872 states: Contract to perform promise or discharge liability of third person in case of his default. This is an essential provision in contract law in India.

title: Contract Act Section 128: Surety liability
text: Section 128 of the Indian Contract Act, 1872 states: Liability of surety is co-extensive with that of principal debtor unless contrary appears. This is an essential provision in contract law in India.

title: Contract Act Section 129: Continuing guarantee
text: Section 129 of the Indian Contract Act, 1872 states: Guarantee which extends to series of transactions is continuing guarantee. This is an essential provision in contract law in India.

title: Contract Act Section 133: Discharge of surety
text: Section 133 of the Indian Contract Act, 1872 states: Discharge of surety by variance in terms of contract. This is an essential provision in contract law in India.

title: Contract Act Section 148: Bailment defined
text: Section 148 of the Indian Contract Act, 1872 states: Bailment is delivery of goods by one person to another for some purpose upon contract. This is an essential provision in contract law in India.

title: Contract Act Section 151: Care to be taken by bailee
text: Section 151 of the Indian Contract Act, 1872 states: Bailee must take care of goods bailed as man of ordinary prudence would take. This is an essential provision in contract law in India.

title: Contract Act Section 152: Bailee not responsible
text: Section 152 of the Indian Contract Act, 1872 states: Bailee not responsible for loss, destruction or deterioration if he took care required. This is an essential provision in contract law in India.

title: Contract Act Section 160: Bailee's duty to return
text: Section 160 of the Indian Contract Act, 1872 states: Bailee must return goods on expiry of time or accomplishment of purpose. This is an essential provision in contract law in India.

title: Contract Act Section 172: Pledge defined
text: Section 172 of the Indian Contract Act, 1872 states: Pledge is bailment of goods as security for payment of debt or performance of promise. This is an essential provision in contract law in India.

title: Contract Act Section 176: Pawnee's right
text: Section 176 of the Indian Contract Act, 1872 states: Pawnee may retain goods as security for interest on debt. This is an essential provision in contract law in India.

title: Contract Act Section 182: Agent defined
text: Section 182 of the Indian Contract Act, 1872 states: Agent is person employed to do any act or represent another in dealings with third person. This is an essential provision in contract law in India.

title: Contract Act Section 183: Who may employ agent
text: Section 183 of the Indian Contract Act, 1872 states: Any person who is of age of majority and sound mind may employ agent. This is an essential provision in contract law in India.

title: Contract Act Section 186: Agent's authority
text: Section 186 of the Indian Contract Act, 1872 states: Agent's authority may be expressed or implied from circumstances. This is an essential provision in contract law in India.

title: Contract Act Section 201: Agent's duty
text: Section 201 of the Indian Contract Act, 1872 states: Agent must conduct business according to directions or custom which prevails. This is an essential provision in contract law in India.

title: Contract Act Section 215: Right of principal
text: Section 215 of the Indian Contract Act, 1872 states: Principal when bound by acts done in good faith. This is an essential provision in contract law in India.

title: Contract Act Section 218: Termination of agent
text: Section 218 of the Indian Contract Act, 1872 states: Termination of agency by principal revoking authority or by agent renouncing business. This is an essential provision in contract law in India.

title: Fundamental Rights - Complete Guide
text: The Fundamental Rights in India are enshrined in Part III (Articles 12-35) of the Constitution. These rights are essential for the development of human personality and are guaranteed by the Constitution. The six categories of fundamental rights are: 1) Right to Equality (Articles 14-18), 2) Right to Freedom (Articles 19-22), 3) Right against Exploitation (Articles 23-24), 4) Right to Freedom of Religion (Articles 25-28), 5) Cultural and Educational Rights (Articles 29-30), and 6) Right to Constitutional Remedies (Article 32). These rights can be enforced through writ petitions in the Supreme Court under Article 32 or in High Courts under Article 226. The Supreme Court has expanded the scope of these rights through various landmark judgments.
citations: Kesavananda Bharati v. State of Kerala
Maneka Gandhi v. Union of India

title: Article 14 - Equality Before Law
text: Article 14 states: 'The State shall not deny to any person equality before the law or the equal protection of the laws within the territory of India.' This article ensures that all persons are equal before the law and are entitled to equal protection of laws. It prohibits discrimination on grounds of religion, race, caste, sex, or place of birth. The principle of equality is a fundamental feature of the Indian Constitution and forms the basis of democracy. The Supreme Court has interpreted this article to include the concept of 'reasonable classification' where equals are treated equally and unequals are treated differently based on intelligible differentia.
citations: State of West Bengal v. Anwar Ali Sarkar
E.P. Royappa v. State of Tamil Nadu

title: Article 19 - Freedom of Speech and Expression
text: Article 19(1)(a) guarantees the right to freedom of speech and expression to all citizens. This includes the right to express one's views, opinions, and ideas through any medium including print, electronic, and digital media. However, this right is subject to reasonable restrictions under Article 19(2) in the interests of sovereignty and integrity of India, security of the State, friendly relations with foreign States, public order, decency or morality, contempt of court, defamation, or incitement to an offence. The Supreme Court has held that this right includes the right to information, right to criticize government policies, and right to commercial speech.
citations: Romesh Thapar v. State of Madras
Sakal Papers v. Union of India

title: Article 21 - Right to Life and Personal Liberty
text: Article 21 states: 'No person shall be deprived of his life or personal liberty except according to procedure established by law.' This article has been interpreted broadly by the Supreme Court to include the right to live with human dignity, right to livelihood, right to health, right to education, right to privacy, right to clean environment, and right to die with dignity. It forms the foundation of human rights in India and has been used to expand the scope of fundamental rights through judicial activism. The procedure established by law must be fair, just, and reasonable.
citations: Maneka Gandhi v. Union of India

title: Article 32 - Right to Constitutional Remedies
text: Article 32 provides the right to move the Supreme Court for the enforcement of fundamental rights. It is called the 'heart and soul' of the Constitution by Dr. B.R. Ambedkar. The Supreme Court can issue writs like Habeas Corpus (to produce a person), Mandamus (to command public authority), Prohibition (to prevent lower court from exceeding jurisdiction), Certiorari (to quash lower court decision), and Quo Warranto (to question authority of public office holder). This article makes fundamental rights justiciable and enforceable. It is a fundamental right itself and cannot be suspended except during emergency.
citations: Kesavananda Bharati v. State of Kerala
Minerva Mills v. Union of India

title: Writ Petitions - Complete Guide
text: Writ petitions are formal written applications to a court requesting judicial action. In India, five types of writs are available under Articles 32 and 226: 1) Habeas Corpus - to produce a person before the court and ensure their liberty, 2) Mandamus - to command a public authority to perform its legal duty, 3) Prohibition - to prevent a lower court from exceeding its jurisdiction, 4) Certiorari - to quash the decision of a lower court or tribunal, and 5) Quo Warranto - to question the authority of a person holding a public office. These writs are essential for protecting fundamental rights and ensuring good governance.
citations: State of Orissa v. Madan Gopal

title: Criminal Law - IPC Overview
text: The Indian Penal Code (IPC) is the main criminal law of India. It defines various offences and their punishments. Key sections include: Section 299-304 (Culpable Homicide and Murder), Section 307-308 (Attempt to Murder), Section 375-376 (Rape), Section 420 (Cheating), Section 406 (Criminal Breach of Trust), Section 498A (Cruelty by Husband), Section 304B (Dowry Death), and Section 302 (Murder). The IPC is supplemented by various special laws like the Prevention of Corruption Act, Narcotic Drugs and Psychotropic Substances Act, and Information Technology Act.
citations: State of Maharashtra v. Prafull B. Desai
State of Punjab v. Gurmit Singh

title: Civil Procedure Code - Key Provisions
text: The Code of Civil Procedure (CPC) governs civil proceedings in India. Key provisions include: Order 1 (Parties to Suits), Order 2 (Frame of Suit), Order 6 (Pleadings), Order 7 (Plaint), Order 8 (Written Statement), Order 9 (Appearance of Parties), Order 10 (Examination of Parties), Order 11 (Discovery and Inspection), Order 12 (Admissions), Order 13 (Production of Documents), Order 14 (Issues), Order 15 (Disposal of Suit), Order 16 (Summoning and Attendance of Witnesses), Order 17 (Adjournments), Order 18 (Hearing of Suit), Order 19 (Affidavits), Order 20 (Judgment), Order 21 (Execution of Decrees), Order 22 (Death of Parties), Order 23 (Withdrawal and Adjustment), Order 24 (Payment into Court), Order 25 (Security for Costs), Order 26 (Commissions), Order 27 (Suits by or against Government), Order 28 (Suits by or against Military Personnel), Order 29 (Suits by or against Corporations), Order 30 (Suits by or against Firms), Order 31 (Suits by or against Trustees), Order 32 (Suits by or against Minors), Order 33 (Suits by Indigent Persons), Order 34 (Suits relating to Mortgages), Order 35 (Interpleader), Order 36 (Special Case), Order 37 (Summary Procedure), Order 38 (Arrest before Judgment), Order 39 (Temporary Injunctions), Order 40 (Appointment of Receivers), Order 41 (Appeals from Original Decrees), Order 42 (Appeals from Appellate Decrees), Order 43 (Appeals from Orders), Order 44 (Appeals by Indigent Persons), Order 45 (Appeals to Supreme Court), Order 46 (Reference), Order 47 (Review), Order 48 (Miscellaneous), Order 49 (Chartered High Courts), Order 50 (Provincial Small Cause Courts), Order 51 (Miscellaneous).
citations: State of U.P. v. Jai Bir Singh

title: Right to Equality
text: Ensures equality before law and equal protection of laws Articles covered: Article 14, Article 15, Article 16, Article 17, Article 18. Enforcement: Can be enforced through writ petitions under Article 32 (Supreme Court) or Article 226 (High Courts)

metadata.enforcement: Can be enforced through writ petitions under Article 32 (Supreme Court) or Article 226 (High Courts)

title: Right to Freedom
text: Includes freedom of speech, assembly, association, movement, residence, and profession Articles covered: Article 19, Article 20, Article 21, Article 22. Enforcement: Enforceable through constitutional remedies and judicial review

metadata.enforcement: Enforceable through constitutional remedies and judicial review

title: Right against Exploitation
text: Prohibits trafficking, forced labor, and child labor Articles covered: Article 23, Article 24. Enforcement: Enforced through criminal law and constitutional remedies

metadata.enforcement: Enforced through criminal law and constitutional remedies

title: Right to Freedom of Religion
text: Freedom to practice, profess, and propagate religion Articles covered: Article 25, Article 26, Article 27, Article 28. Enforcement: Protected through constitutional remedies and secular principles

metadata.enforcement: Protected through constitutional remedies and secular principles

title: Cultural and Educational Rights
text: Right to conserve culture and establish educational institutions Articles covered: Article 29, Article 30. Enforcement: Enforced through constitutional remedies and minority rights

metadata.enforcement: Enforced through constitutional remedies and minority rights

title: Article 14 - Equality before law
text: The State shall not deny to any person equality before the law or the equal protection of the laws within the territory of India.

title: Article 19 - Protection of certain rights regarding freedom of speech
text: All citizens shall have the right to freedom of speech and expression; to assemble peaceably and without arms; to form associations or unions; to move freely throughout the territory of India; to reside and settle in any part of the territory of India; and to practice any profession, or to carry on any occupation, trade or business.

title: Article 21 - Protection of life and personal liberty
text: No person shall be deprived of his life or personal liberty except according to procedure established by law.

title: Article 32 - Remedies for enforcement of rights
text: The right to move the Supreme Court by appropriate proceedings for the enforcement of the rights conferred by this Part is guaranteed.

title: Fundamental Rights in Indian Constitution
text: The Fundamental Rights are enshrined in Part III of the Indian Constitution (Articles 12-35). These rights are essential for the development of human personality and are guaranteed by the Constitution. The main fundamental rights include: Right to Equality (Articles 14-18), Right to Freedom (Articles 19-22), Right against Exploitation (Articles 23-24), Right to Freedom of Religion (Articles 25-28), Cultural and Educational Rights (Articles 29-30), and Right to Constitutional Remedies (Article 32). These rights can be enforced through writ petitions in the Supreme Court under Article 32 or in High Courts under Article 226.

title: Article 14 - Equality before Law
text: Article 14 of the Indian Constitution states: 'The State shall not deny to any person equality before the law or the equal protection of the laws within the territory of India.' This article ensures that all persons are equal before the law and are entitled to equal protection of laws. It prohibits discrimination on grounds of religion, race, caste, sex, or place of birth. The principle of equality is a fundamental feature of the Indian Constitution and forms the basis of democracy.

title: Article 19 - Freedom of Speech and Expression
text: Article 19(1)(a) guarantees the right to freedom of speech and expression to all citizens. This includes the right to express one's views, opinions, and ideas through any medium. However, this right is subject to reasonable restrictions under Article 19(2) in the interests of sovereignty and integrity of India, security of the State, friendly relations with foreign States, public order, decency or morality, contempt of court, defamation, or incitement to an offence.

title: Article 21 - Right to Life and Personal Liberty
text: Article 21 states: 'No person shall be deprived of his life or personal liberty except according to procedure established by law.' This article has been interpreted broadly by the Supreme Court to include the right to live with human dignity, right to livelihood, right to health, right to education, and right to privacy. It is one of the most important fundamental rights and forms the foundation of human rights in India.

title: Article 32 - Right to Constitutional Remedies
text: Article 32 provides the right to move the Supreme Court for the enforcement of fundamental rights. It is called the 'heart and soul' of the Constitution by Dr. B.R. Ambedkar. The Supreme Court can issue writs like Habeas Corpus, Mandamus, Prohibition, Certiorari, and Quo Warranto for the enforcement of fundamental rights. This article makes fundamental rights justiciable and enforceable.

title: Writ Petitions in Indian Law
text: Writ petitions are formal written applications to a court requesting judicial action. In India, five types of writs are available under Articles 32 and 226: 1) Habeas Corpus - to produce a person before the court, 2) Mandamus - to command a public authority to perform its duty, 3) Prohibition - to prevent a lower court from exceeding its jurisdiction, 4) Certiorari - to quash the decision of a lower court, and 5) Quo Warranto - to question the authority of a person holding a public office.

title: Legal Term: Fundamental Rights
text: Definition: Basic human rights guaranteed by the Indian Constitution under Part III. Examples: Right to Equality, Right to Freedom, Right against Exploitation

title: Legal Term: Writ Petition
text: Definition: A formal written application to a court requesting judicial action. Examples: Habeas Corpus, Mandamus, Prohibition, Certiorari, Quo Warranto

title: Legal Term: Constitutional Remedy
text: Definition: Legal recourse available under Articles 32 and 226 of the Constitution. Examples: Supreme Court writs, High Court writs, Constitutional petitions

title: Legal Term: Judicial Review
text: Definition: Power of courts to review and invalidate unconstitutional laws or actions. Examples: Constitutional validity, Administrative review, Legislative review

title: Culpable Homicide
text:
Whoever causes death by doing an act with the intention of causing death, or with the intention of causing such bodily injury as is likely to cause death, or with the knowledge that he is likely by such act to cause death, commits the offence of culpable homicide.

Punishment: Life imprisonment or imprisonment up to 10 years

metadata.punishment: Life imprisonment or imprisonment up to 10 years

title: Murder
text:
Whoever commits murder shall be punished with death, or imprisonment for life, and shall also be liable to fine.

Punishment: Death penalty or life imprisonment

title: Definition of State
text: In this Part, unless the context otherwise requires, 'the State' includes the Government and Parliament of India and the Government and the Legislature of each of the States and all local or other authorities within the territory of India or under the control of the Government of India.

title: Laws inconsistent with or in derogation of the fundamental rights
text: All laws in force in the territory of India immediately before the commencement of this Constitution, in so far as they are inconsistent with the provisions of this Part, shall, to the extent of such inconsistency, be void. The State shall not make any law which takes away or abridges the rights conferred by this Part and any law made in contravention of this clause shall, to the extent of the contravention, be void.

title: Equality before law
text: The State shall not deny to any person equality before the law or the equal protection of the laws within the territory of India.
citations: State of West Bengal v. Anwar Ali Sarkar

title: Prohibition of discrimination on grounds of religion, race, caste, sex or place of birth
text: The State shall not discriminate against any citizen on grounds only of religion, race, caste, sex, place of birth or any of them. No citizen shall, on grounds only of religion, race, caste, sex, place of birth or any of them, be subject to any disability, liability, restriction or condition with regard to access to shops, public restaurants, hotels and places of public entertainment.

title: Protection of certain rights regarding freedom of speech
text: All citizens shall have the right to freedom of speech and expression; to assemble peaceably and without arms; to form associations or unions; to move freely throughout the territory of India; to reside and settle in any part of the territory of India; and to practice any profession, or to carry on any occupation, trade or business.
citations: Romesh Thapar v. State of Madras

title: Protection of life and personal liberty
text: No person shall be deprived of his life or personal liberty except according to procedure established by law.
citations: Maneka Gandhi v. Union of India

title: Remedies for enforcement of rights conferred by this Part
text: The right to move the Supreme Court by appropriate proceedings for the enforcement of the rights conferred by this Part is guaranteed. The Supreme Court shall have power to issue directions or orders or writs, including writs in the nature of habeas corpus, mandamus, prohibition, quo warranto and certiorari, whichever may be appropriate, for the enforcement of any of the rights conferred by this Part.

title: Fundamental Rights - Complete Guide
citations: Kesavananda Bharati v. State of Kerala
Maneka Gandhi v. Union of India
text: The Fundamental Rights in India are enshrined in Part III (Articles 12-35) of the Constitution. These rights are essential for the development of human personality and are guaranteed by the Constitution. The six categories of fundamental rights are: 1) Right to Equality (Articles 14-18), 2) Right to Freedom (Articles 19-22), 3) Right against Exploitation (Articles 23-24), 4) Right to Freedom of Religion (Articles 25-28), 5) Cultural and Educational Rights (Articles 29-30), and 6) Right to Constitutional Remedies (Article 32). These rights can be enforced through writ petitions in the Supreme Court under Article 32 or in High Courts under Article 226. The Supreme Court has expanded the scope of these rights through various landmark judgments.

title: Article 14 - Equality Before Law
citations: State of West Bengal v. Anwar Ali Sarkar
E.P. Royappa v. State of Tamil Nadu
text: Article 14 states: 'The State shall not deny to any person equality before the law or the equal protection of the laws within the territory of India.' This article ensures that all persons are equal before the law and are entitled to equal protection of laws. It prohibits discrimination on grounds of religion, race, caste, sex, or place of birth. The principle of equality is a fundamental feature of the Indian Constitution and forms the basis of democracy. The Supreme Court has interpreted this article to include the concept of 'reasonable classification' where equals are treated equally and unequals are treated differently based on intelligible differentia.

title: Article 19 - Freedom of Speech and Expression
citations: Romesh Thapar v. State of Madras
Sakal Papers v. Union of India
text: Article 19(1)(a) guarantees the right to freedom of speech and expression to all citizens. This includes the right to express one's views, opinions, and ideas through any medium including print, electronic, and digital media. However, this right is subject to reasonable restrictions under Article 19(2) in the interests of sovereignty and integrity of India, security of the State, friendly relations with foreign States, public order, decency or morality, contempt of court, defamation, or incitement to an offence. The Supreme Court has held that this right includes the right to information, right to criticize government policies, and right to commercial speech.

title: Article 21 - Right to Life and Personal Liberty
citations: Maneka Gandhi v. Union of India
text: Article 21 states: 'No person shall be deprived of his life or personal liberty except according to procedure established by law.' This article has been interpreted broadly by the Supreme Court to include the right to live with human dignity, right to livelihood, right to health, right to education, right to privacy, right to clean environment, and right to die with dignity. It forms the foundation of human rights in India and has been used to expand the scope of fundamental rights through judicial activism. The procedure established by law must be fair, just, and reasonable.

title: Article 32 - Right to Constitutional Remedies
citations: Kesavananda Bharati v. State of Kerala
Minerva Mills v. Union of India
text: Article 32 provides the right to move the Supreme Court for the enforcement of fundamental rights. It is called the 'heart and soul' of the Constitution by Dr. B.R. Ambedkar. The Supreme Court can issue writs like Habeas Corpus (to produce a person), Mandamus (to command public authority), Prohibition (to prevent lower court from exceeding jurisdiction), Certiorari (to quash lower court decision), and Quo Warranto (to question authority of public office holder). This article makes fundamental rights justiciable and enforceable. It is a fundamental right itself and cannot be suspended except during emergency.

title: Writ Petitions - Complete Guide
citations: State of Orissa v. Madan Gopal
text: Writ petitions are formal written applications to a court requesting judicial action. In India, five types of writs are available under Articles 32 and 226: 1) Habeas Corpus - to produce a person before the court and ensure their liberty, 2) Mandamus - to command a public authority to perform its legal duty, 3) Prohibition - to prevent a lower court from exceeding its jurisdiction, 4) Certiorari - to quash the decision of a lower court or tribunal, and 5) Quo Warranto - to question the authority of a person holding a public office. These writs are essential for protecting fundamental rights and ensuring good governance.

title: Criminal Law - IPC Overview
citations: State of Maharashtra v. Prafull B. Desai
State of Punjab v. Gurmit Singh
text: The Indian Penal Code (IPC) is the main criminal law of India. It defines various offences and their punishments. Key sections include: Section 299-304 (Culpable Homicide and Murder), Section 307-308 (Attempt to Murder), Section 375-376 (Rape), Section 420 (Cheating), Section 406 (Criminal Breach of Trust), Section 498A (Cruelty by Husband), Section 304B (Dowry Death), and Section 302 (Murder). The IPC is supplemented by various special laws like the Prevention of Corruption Act, Narcotic Drugs and Psychotropic Substances Act, and Information Technology Act.

title: Civil Procedure Code - Key Provisions
citations: State of U.P. v. Jai Bir Singh
text: The Code of Civil Procedure (CPC) governs civil proceedings in India. Key provisions include: Order 1 (Parties to Suits), Order 2 (Frame of Suit), Order 6 (Pleadings), Order 7 (Plaint), Order 8 (Written Statement), Order 9 (Appearance of Parties), Order 10 (Examination of Parties), Order 11 (Discovery and Inspection), Order 12 (Admissions), Order 13 (Production of Documents), Order 14 (Issues), Order 15 (Disposal of Suit), Order 16 (Summoning and Attendance of Witnesses), Order 17 (Adjournments), Order 18 (Hearing of Suit), Order 19 (Affidavits), Order 20 (Judgment), Order 21 (Execution of Decrees), Order 22 (Death of Parties), Order 23 (Withdrawal and Adjustment), Order 24 (Payment into Court), Order 25 (Security for Costs), Order 26 (Commissions), Order 27 (Suits by or against Government), Order 28 (Suits by or against Military Personnel), Order 29 (Suits by or against Corporations), Order 30 (Suits by or against Firms), Order 31 (Suits by or against Trustees), Order 32 (Suits by or against Minors), Order 33 (Suits by Indigent Persons), Order 34 (Suits relating to Mortgages), Order 35 (Interpleader), Order 36 (Special Case), Order 37 (Summary Procedure), Order 38 (Arrest before Judgment), Order 39 (Temporary Injunctions), Order 40 (Appointment of Receivers), Order 41 (Appeals from Original Decrees), Order 42 (Appeals from Appellate Decrees), Order 43 (Appeals from Orders), Order 44 (Appeals by Indigent Persons), Order 45 (Appeals to Supreme Court), Order 46 (Reference), Order 47 (Review), Order 48 (Miscellaneous), Order 49 (Chartered High Courts), Order 50 (Provincial Small Cause Courts), Order 51 (Miscellaneous).

content: Article 32 provides the right to move the Supreme Court for the enforcement of fundamental rights. It is called the 'heart and soul' of the Constitution by Dr. B.R. Ambedkar. The Supreme Court can issue writs like Habeas Corpus, Mandamus, Prohibition, Certiorari, and Quo Warranto for the enforcement of fundamental rights. This article makes fundamental rights justiciable and enforceable.
text: Article 32 provides the right to move the Supreme Court for the enforcement of fundamental rights. It is called the 'heart and soul' of the Constitution by Dr. B.R. Ambedkar. The Supreme Court can issue writs like Habeas Corpus, Mandamus, Prohibition, Certiorari, and Quo Warranto for the enforcement of fundamental rights. This article makes fundamental rights justiciable and enforceable.

title: Writ Petitions in Indian Law
content: Writ petitions are formal written applications to a court requesting judicial action. In India, five types of writs are available under Articles 32 and 226: 1) Habeas Corpus - to produce a person before the court, 2) Mandamus - to command a public authority to perform its duty, 3) Prohibition - to prevent a lower court from exceeding its jurisdiction, 4) Certiorari - to quash the decision of a lower court, and 5) Quo Warranto - to question the authority of a person holding a public office.
text: Writ petitions are formal written applications to a court requesting judicial action. In India, five types of writs are available under Articles 32 and 226: 1) Habeas Corpus - to produce a person before the court, 2) Mandamus - to command a public authority to perform its duty, 3) Prohibition - to prevent a lower court from exceeding its jurisdiction, 4) Certiorari - to quash the decision of a lower court, and 5) Quo Warranto - to question the authority of a person holding a public office.

definition: Basic human rights guaranteed by the Indian Constitution under Part III
title: Untitled
Culpable Homicide
content: Whoever causes death by doing an act with the intention of causing death, or with the intention of causing such bodily injury as is likely to cause death, or with the knowledge that he is likely by such act to cause death, commits the offence of culpable homicide.
punishment: Life imprisonment or imprisonment up to 10 years
text: Whoever causes death by doing an act with the intention of causing death, or with the intention of causing such bodily injury as is likely to cause death, or with the knowledge that he is likely by such act to cause death, commits the offence of culpable homicide.

title: Murder
content: Whoever commits murder shall be punished with death, or imprisonment for life, and shall also be liable to fine.
text: Whoever commits murder shall be punished with death, or imprisonment for life, and shall also be liable to fine.

title: Definition of State
content: In this Part, unless the context otherwise requires, 'the State' includes the Government and Parliament of India and the Government and the Legislature of each of the States and all local or other authorities within the territory of India or under the control of the Government of India.
text: In this Part, unless the context otherwise requires, 'the State' includes the Government and Parliament of India and the Government and the Legislature of each of the States and all local or other authorities within the territory of India or under the control of the Government of India.

title: Laws inconsistent with or in derogation of the fundamental rights
content: All laws in force in the territory of India immediately before the commencement of this Constitution, in so far as they are inconsistent with the provisions of this Part, shall, to the extent of such inconsistency, be void. The State shall not make any law which takes away or abridges the rights conferred by this Part and any law made in contravention of this clause shall, to the extent of the contravention, be void.
text: All laws in force in the territory of India immediately before the commencement of this Constitution, in so far as they are inconsistent with the provisions of this Part, shall, to the extent of such inconsistency, be void. The State shall not make any law which takes away or abridges the rights conferred by this Part and any law made in contravention of this clause shall, to the extent of the contravention, be void.

title: Equality before law
content: The State shall not deny to any person equality before the law or the equal protection of the laws within the territory of India.
citations: State of West Bengal v. Anwar Ali Sarkar
text: The State shall not deny to any person equality before the law or the equal protection of the laws within the territory of India.

title: Prohibition of discrimination on grounds of religion, race, caste, sex or place of birth
content: The State shall not discriminate against any citizen on grounds only of religion, race, caste, sex, place of birth or any of them. No citizen shall, on grounds only of religion, race, caste, sex, place of birth or any of them, be subject to any disability, liability, restriction or condition with regard to access to shops, public restaurants, hotels and places of public entertainment.
text: The State shall not discriminate against any citizen on grounds only of religion, race, caste, sex, place of birth or any of them. No citizen shall, on grounds only of religion, race, caste, sex, place of birth or any of them, be subject to any disability, liability, restriction or condition with regard to access to shops, public restaurants, hotels and places of public entertainment.

title: Protection of certain rights regarding freedom of speech
content: All citizens shall have the right to freedom of speech and expression; to assemble peaceably and without arms; to form associations or unions; to move freely throughout the territory of India; to reside and settle in any part of the territory of India; and to practice any profession, or to carry on any occupation, trade or business.
citations: Romesh Thapar v. State of Madras
text: All citizens shall have the right to freedom of speech and expression; to assemble peaceably and without arms; to form associations or unions; to move freely throughout the territory of India; to reside and settle in any part of the territory of India; and to practice any profession, or to carry on any occupation, trade or business.

title: Protection of life and personal liberty
content: No person shall be deprived of his life or personal liberty except according to procedure established by law.
citations: Maneka Gandhi v. Union of India
text: No person shall be deprived of his life or personal liberty except according to procedure established by law.

title: Remedies for enforcement of rights conferred by this Part
content: The right to move the Supreme Court by appropriate proceedings for the enforcement of the rights conferred by this Part is guaranteed. The Supreme Court shall have power to issue directions or orders or writs, including writs in the nature of habeas corpus, mandamus, prohibition, quo warranto and certiorari, whichever may be appropriate, for the enforcement of any of the rights conferred by this Part.
text: The right to move the Supreme Court by appropriate proceedings for the enforcement of the rights conferred by this Part is guaranteed. The Supreme Court shall have power to issue directions or orders or writs, including writs in the nature of habeas corpus, mandamus, prohibition, quo warranto and certiorari, whichever may be appropriate, for the enforcement of any of the rights conferred by this Part.

case_name: Kesavananda Bharati v. State of Kerala
summary: Landmark case that established the basic structure doctrine of the Constitution
key_points: Parliament cannot amend the basic structure of the Constitution
Fundamental rights are part of the basic structure
Judicial review is essential for democracy

Q: Define Evidence Act Section 126: Professional privilege - legal advisers
A: Section 126 of the Indian Evidence Act, 1872 states: No barrister, attorney, pleader or vakil shall be permitted to disclose any communication made to him. This is a fundamental provision in the law of evidence in India.

title: What is Fundamental Rights - Complete Guide?
text:
Q: What is Fundamental Rights - Complete Guide?
A: The Fundamental Rights in India are enshrined in Part III (Articles 12-35) of the Constitution. These rights are essential for the development of human personality and are guaranteed by the Constitution. The six categories of fundamental rights are: 1) Right to Equality (Articles 14-18), 2) Right to Freedom (Articles 19-22), 3) Right against Exploitation (Articles 23-24), 4) Right to Freedom of Religion (Articles 25-28), 5) Cultural and Educational Rights (Articles 29-30), and 6) Right to Constitutional Remedies (Article 32). These rights can be enforced through writ petitions in the Supreme Court under Article 32 or in High Courts under Article 226. The Supreme Court has expanded the scope of these rights through various landmark judgments.

title: What is Article 14 - Equality Before Law?
text:
Q: What is Article 14 - Equality Before Law?
A: Article 14 states: 'The State shall not deny to any person equality before the law or the equal protection of the laws within the territory of India.' This article ensures that all persons are equal before the law and are entitled to equal protection of laws. It prohibits discrimination on grounds of religion, race, caste, sex, or place of birth. The principle of equality is a fundamental feature of the Indian Constitution and forms the basis of democracy. The Supreme Court has interpreted this article to include the concept of 'reasonable classification' where equals are treated equally and unequals are treated differently based on intelligible differentia.

title: What is Article 19 - Freedom of Speech and Expression?
text:
Q: What is Article 19 - Freedom of Speech and Expression?
A: Article 19(1)(a) guarantees the right to freedom of speech and expression to all citizens. This includes the right to express one's views, opinions, and ideas through any medium including print, electronic, and digital media. However, this right is subject to reasonable restrictions under Article 19(2) in the interests of sovereignty and integrity of India, security of the State, friendly relations with foreign States, public order, decency or morality, contempt of court, defamation, or incitement to an offence. The Supreme Court has held that this right includes the right to information, right to criticize government policies, and right to commercial speech.

title: What is Article 21 - Right to Life and Personal Liberty?
text:
Q: What is Article 21 - Right to Life and Personal Liberty?
A: Article 21 states: 'No person shall be deprived of his life or personal liberty except according to procedure established by law.' This article has been interpreted broadly by the Supreme Court to include the right to live with human dignity, right to livelihood, right to health, right to education, right to privacy, right to clean environment, and right to die with dignity. It forms the foundation of human rights in India and has been used to expand the scope of fundamental rights through judicial activism. The procedure established by law must be fair, just, and reasonable.

title: What is Article 32 - Right to Constitutional Remedies?
text:
Q: What is Article 32 - Right to Constitutional Remedies?
A: Article 32 provides the right to move the Supreme Court for the enforcement of fundamental rights. It is called the 'heart and soul' of the Constitution by Dr. B.R. Ambedkar. The Supreme Court can issue writs like Habeas Corpus (to produce a person), Mandamus (to command public authority), Prohibition (to prevent lower court from exceeding jurisdiction), Certiorari (to quash lower court decision), and Quo Warranto (to question authority of public office holder). This article makes fundamental rights justiciable and enforceable. It is a fundamental right itself and cannot be suspended except during emergency.

title: What is Writ Petitions - Complete Guide?
text:
Q: What is Writ Petitions - Complete Guide?
A: Writ petitions are formal written applications to a court requesting judicial action. In India, five types of writs are available under Articles 32 and 226: 1) Habeas Corpus - to produce a person before the court and ensure their liberty, 2) Mandamus - to command a public authority to perform its legal duty, 3) Prohibition - to prevent a lower court from exceeding its jurisdiction, 4) Certiorari - to quash the decision of a lower court or tribunal, and 5) Quo Warranto - to question the authority of a person holding a public office. These writs are essential for protecting fundamental rights and ensuring good governance.

title: What is Criminal Law - IPC Overview?
text:
Q: What is Criminal Law - IPC Overview?
A: The Indian Penal Code (IPC) is the main criminal law of India. It defines various offences and their punishments. Key sections include: Section 299-304 (Culpable Homicide and Murder), Section 307-308 (Attempt to Murder), Section 375-376 (Rape), Section 420 (Cheating), Section 406 (Criminal Breach of Trust), Section 498A (Cruelty by Husband), Section 304B (Dowry Death), and Section 302 (Murder). The IPC is supplemented by various special laws like the Prevention of Corruption Act, Narcotic Drugs and Psychotropic Substances Act, and Information Technology Act.

Key sections include: Section 299-304 (Culpable Homicide and Murder), Section 307-308 (Attempt to Murder), Section 375-376 (Rape), Section 420 (Cheating), Section 406 (Criminal Breach of Trust), Section 498A (Cruelty by Husband), Section 304B (Dowry Death), and Section 302 (Murder). The IPC is supplemented by various special laws like the Prevention of Corruption Act, Narcotic Drugs and Psychotropic Substances Act, and Information Technology Act.

title: What is Fundamental Rights in Indian Constitution?
text:
Q: What is Fundamental Rights in Indian Constitution?
A: The Fundamental Rights are enshrined in Part III of the Indian Constitution (Articles 12-35). These rights are essential for the development of human personality and are guaranteed by the Constitution. The main fundamental rights include: Right to Equality (Articles 14-18), Right to Freedom (Articles 19-22), Right against Exploitation (Articles 23-24), Right to Freedom of Religion (Articles 25-28), Cultural and Educational Rights (Articles 29-30), and Right to Constitutional Remedies (Article 32). These rights can be enforced through writ petitions in the Supreme Court under Article 32 or in High Courts under Article 226.

title: What is Article 14 - Equality before Law?
text:
Q: What is Article 14 - Equality before Law?
A: Article 14 of the Indian Constitution states: 'The State shall not deny to any person equality before the law or the equal protection of the laws within the territory of India.' This article ensures that all persons are equal before the law and are entitled to equal protection of laws. It prohibits discrimination on grounds of religion, race, caste, sex, or place of birth. The principle of equality is a fundamental feature of the Indian Constitution and forms the basis of democracy.

title: What is Article 19 - Freedom of Speech and Expression?
text:
Q: What is Article 19 - Freedom of Speech and Expression?
A: Article 19(1)(a) guarantees the right to freedom of speech and expression to all citizens. This includes the right to express one's views, opinions, and ideas through any medium. However, this right is subject to reasonable restrictions under Article 19(2) in the interests of sovereignty and integrity of India, security of the State, friendly relations with foreign States, public order, decency or morality, contempt of court, defamation, or incitement to an offence.

title: What is Article 21 - Right to Life and Personal Liberty?
text:
Q: What is Article 21 - Right to Life and Personal Liberty?
A: Article 21 states: 'No person shall be deprived of his life or personal liberty except according to procedure established by law.' This article has been interpreted broadly by the Supreme Court to include the right to live with human dignity, right to livelihood, right to health, right to education, and right to privacy. It is one of the most important fundamental rights and forms the foundation of human rights in India.

title: What is Article 32 - Right to Constitutional Remedies?
text:
Q: What is Article 32 - Right to Constitutional Remedies?
A: Article 32 provides the right to move the Supreme Court for the enforcement of fundamental rights. It is called the 'heart and soul' of the Constitution by Dr. B.R. Ambedkar. The Supreme Court can issue writs like Habeas Corpus, Mandamus, Prohibition, Certiorari, and Quo Warranto for the enforcement of fundamental rights. This article makes fundamental rights justiciable and enforceable.

title: What is Writ Petitions in Indian Law?
text:
Q: What is Writ Petitions in Indian Law?
A: Writ petitions are formal written applications to a court requesting judicial action. In India, five types of writs are available under Articles 32 and 226: 1) Habeas Corpus - to produce a person before the court, 2) Mandamus - to command a public authority to perform its duty, 3) Prohibition - to prevent a lower court from exceeding its jurisdiction, 4) Certiorari - to quash the decision of a lower court, and 5) Quo Warranto - to question the authority of a person holding a public office.

title: What is Culpable Homicide?
text:
Q: What is Culpable Homicide?
A: Whoever causes death by doing an act with the intention of causing death, or with the intention of causing such bodily injury as is likely to cause death, or with the knowledge that he is likely by such act to cause death, commits the offence of culpable homicide.

Punishment: Life imprisonment or imprisonment up to 10 years

title: What is Definition of State?
text:
Q: What is Definition of State?
A: In this Part, unless the context otherwise requires, 'the State' includes the Government and Parliament of India and the Government and the Legislature of each of the States and all local or other authorities within the territory of India or under the control of the Government of India.

title: What is Laws inconsistent with or in derogation of the fundamental rights?
text:
Q: What is Laws inconsistent with or in derogation of the fundamental rights?
A: All laws in force in the territory of India immediately before the commencement of this Constitution, in so far as they are inconsistent with the provisions of this Part, shall, to the extent of such inconsistency, be void. The State shall not make any law which takes away or abridges the rights conferred by this Part and any law made in contravention of this clause shall, to the extent of the contravention, be void.

text:
Q: Define Laws inconsistent with or in derogation of the fundamental rights
A: All laws in force in the territory of India immediately before the commencement of this Constitution, in so far as they are inconsistent with the provisions of this Part, shall, to the extent of such inconsistency, be void. The State shall not make any law which takes away or abridges the rights conferred by this Part and any law made in contravention of this clause shall, to the extent of the contravention, be void.

title: What is Remedies for enforcement of rights conferred by this Part?
text:
Q: What is Remedies for enforcement of rights conferred by this Part?
A: The right to move the Supreme Court by appropriate proceedings for the enforcement of the rights conferred by this Part is guaranteed. The Supreme Court shall have power to issue directions or orders or writs, including writs in the nature of habeas corpus, mandamus, prohibition, quo warranto and certiorari, whichever may be appropriate, for the enforcement of any of the rights conferred by this Part.

title: What is Fundamental Rights - Complete Guide?
text:
Q: What is Fundamental Rights - Complete Guide?
A: The Fundamental Rights in India are enshrined in Part III (Articles 12-35) of the Constitution. These rights are essential for the development of human personality and are guaranteed by the Constitution. The six categories of fundamental rights are: 1) Right to Equality (Articles 14-18), 2) Right to Freedom (Articles 19-22), 3) Right against Exploitation (Articles 23-24), 4) Right to Freedom of Religion (Articles 25-28), 5) Cultural and Educational Rights (Articles 29-30), and 6) Right to Constitutional Remedies (Article 32). These rights can be enforced through writ petitions in the Supreme Court under Article 32 or in High Courts under Article 226. The Supreme Court has expanded the scope of these rights through various landmark judgments.

title: What is Article 14 - Equality Before Law?
text:
Q: What is Article 14 - Equality Before Law?
A: Article 14 states: 'The State shall not deny to any person equality before the law or the equal protection of the laws within the territory of India.' This article ensures that all persons are equal before the law and are entitled to equal protection of laws. It prohibits discrimination on grounds of religion, race, caste, sex, or place of birth. The principle of equality is a fundamental feature of the Indian Constitution and forms the basis of democracy. The Supreme Court has interpreted this article to include the concept of 'reasonable classification' where equals are treated equally and unequals are treated differently based on intelligible differentia.

title: What is Article 19 - Freedom of Speech and Expression?
text:
Q: What is Article 19 - Freedom of Speech and Expression?
A: Article 19(1)(a) guarantees the right to freedom of speech and expression to all citizens. This includes the right to express one's views, opinions, and ideas through any medium including print, electronic, and digital media. However, this right is subject to reasonable restrictions under Article 19(2) in the interests of sovereignty and integrity of India, security of the State, friendly relations with foreign States, public order, decency or morality, contempt of court, defamation, or incitement to an offence. The Supreme Court has held that this right includes the right to information, right to criticize government policies, and right to commercial speech.

title: What is Article 21 - Right to Life and Personal Liberty?
text:
Q: What is Article 21 - Right to Life and Personal Liberty?
A: Article 21 states: 'No person shall be deprived of his life or personal liberty except according to procedure established by law.' This article has been interpreted broadly by the Supreme Court to include the right to live with human dignity, right to livelihood, right to health, right to education, right to privacy, right to clean environment, and right to die with dignity. It forms the foundation of human rights in India and has been used to expand the scope of fundamental rights through judicial activism. The procedure established by law must be fair, just, and reasonable.
