title: What is Article 32 - Right to Constitutional Remedies?
text:
Q: What is Article 32 - Right to Constitutional Remedies?
A: Article 32 provides the right to move the Supreme Court for the enforcement of fundamental rights. It is called the 'heart and soul' of the Constitution by Dr. B.R. Ambedkar. The Supreme Court can issue writs like Habeas Corpus (to produce a person), Mandamus (to command public authority), Prohibition (to prevent lower court from exceeding jurisdiction), Certiorari (to quash lower court decision), and Quo Warranto (to question authority of public office holder). This article makes fundamental rights justiciable and enforceable. It is a fundamental right itself and cannot be suspended except during emergency.

title: What is Writ Petitions - Complete Guide?
text:
Q: What is Writ Petitions - Complete Guide?
A: Writ petitions are formal written applications to a court requesting judicial action. In India, five types of writs are available under Articles 32 and 226: 1) Habeas Corpus - to produce a person before the court and ensure their liberty, 2) Mandamus - to command a public authority to perform its legal duty, 3) Prohibition - to prevent a lower court from exceeding its jurisdiction, 4) Certiorari - to quash the decision of a lower court or tribunal, and 5) Quo Warranto - to question the authority of a person holding a public office. These writs are essential for protecting fundamental rights and ensuring good governance.

title: What is Criminal Law - IPC Overview?
text:
Q: What is Criminal Law - IPC Overview?
A: The Indian Penal Code (IPC) is the main criminal law of India. It defines various offences and their punishments. Key sections include: Section 299-304 (Culpable Homicide and Murder), Section 307-308 (Attempt to Murder), Section 375-376 (Rape), Section 420 (Cheating), Section 406 (Criminal Breach of Trust), Section 498A (Cruelty by Husband), Section 304B (Dowry Death), and Section 302 (Murder). The IPC is supplemented by various special laws like the Prevention of Corruption Act, Narcotic Drugs and Psychotropic Substances Act, and Information Technology Act.

A: The Indian Penal Code (IPC) is the main criminal law of India. It defines various offences and their punishments. Key sections include: Section 299-304 (Culpable Homicide and Murder), Section 307-308 (Attempt to Murder), Section 375-376 (Rape), Section 420 (Cheating), Section 406 (Criminal Breach of Trust), Section 498A (Cruelty by Husband), Section 304B (Dowry Death), and Section 302 (Murder). The IPC is supplemented by various special laws like the Prevention of Corruption Act, Narcotic Drugs and Psychotropic Substances Act, and Information Technology Act.

title: What is Fundamental Rights in Indian Constitution?
text:
Q: What is Fundamental Rights in Indian Constitution?
A: The Fundamental Rights are enshrined in Part III of the Indian Constitution (Articles 12-35). These rights are essential for the development of human personality and are guaranteed by the Constitution. The main fundamental rights include: Right to Equality (Articles 14-18), Right to Freedom (Articles 19-22), Right against Exploitation (Articles 23-24), Right to Freedom of Religion (Articles 25-28), Cultural and Educational Rights (Articles 29-30), and Right to Constitutional Remedies (Article 32). These rights can be enforced through writ petitions in the Supreme Court under Article 32 or in High Courts under Article 226.

title: What is Article 14 - Equality before Law?
text:
Q: What is Article 14 - Equality before Law?
A: Article 14 of the Indian Constitution states: 'The State shall not deny to any person equality before the law or the equal protection of the laws within the territory of India.' This article ensures that all persons are equal before the law and are entitled to equal protection of laws. It prohibits discrimination on grounds of religion, race, caste, sex, or place of birth. The principle of equality is a fundamental feature of the Indian Constitution and forms the basis of democracy.

title: What is Article 19 - Freedom of Speech and Expression?
text:
Q: What is Article 19 - Freedom of Speech and Expression?
A: Article 19(1)(a) guarantees the right to freedom of speech and expression to all citizens. This includes the right to express one's views, opinions, and ideas through any medium. However, this right is subject to reasonable restrictions under Article 19(2) in the interests of sovereignty and integrity of India, security of the State, friendly relations with foreign States, public order, decency or morality, contempt of court, defamation, or incitement to an offence.

title: What is Article 21 - Right to Life and Personal Liberty?
text:
Q: What is Article 21 - Right to Life and Personal Liberty?
A: Article 21 states: 'No person shall be deprived of his life or personal liberty except according to procedure established by law.' This article has been interpreted broadly by the Supreme Court to include the right to live with human dignity, right to livelihood, right to health, right to education, and right to privacy. It is one of the most important fundamental rights and forms the foundation of human rights in India.

title: What is Article 32 - Right to Constitutional Remedies?
text:
Q: What is Article 32 - Right to Constitutional Remedies?
A: Article 32 provides the right to move the Supreme Court for the enforcement of fundamental rights. It is called the 'heart and soul' of the Constitution by Dr. B.R. Ambedkar. The Supreme Court can issue writs like Habeas Corpus, Mandamus, Prohibition, Certiorari, and Quo Warranto for the enforcement of fundamental rights. This article makes fundamental rights justiciable and enforceable.

title: What is Writ Petitions in Indian Law?
text:
Q: What is Writ Petitions in Indian Law?
A: Writ petitions are formal written applications to a court requesting judicial action. In India, five types of writs are available under Articles 32 and 226: 1) Habeas Corpus - to produce a person before the court, 2) Mandamus - to command a public authority to perform its duty, 3) Prohibition - to prevent a lower court from exceeding its jurisdiction, 4) Certiorari - to quash the decision of a lower court, and 5) Quo Warranto - to question the authority of a person holding a public office.

title: Explain Writ Petitions in Indian Law

text:
Q: What does Writ Petitions in Indian Law state?
A: Writ petitions are formal written applications to a court requesting judicial action. In India, five types of writs are available under Articles 32 and 226: 1) Habeas Corpus - to produce a person before the court, 2) Mandamus - to command a public authority to perform its duty, 3) Prohibition - to prevent a lower court from exceeding its jurisdiction, 4) Certiorari - to quash the decision of a lower court, and 5) Quo Warranto - to question the authority of a person holding a public office.

title: What is Culpable Homicide?
text:
Q: What is Culpable Homicide?
A: Whoever causes death by doing an act with the intention of causing death, or with the intention of causing such bodily injury as is likely to cause death, or with the knowledge that he is likely by such act to cause death, commits the offence of culpable homicide.

title: What is Definition of State?
text:
Q: What is Definition of State?
A: In this Part, unless the context otherwise requires, 'the State' includes the Government and Parliament of India and the Government and the Legislature of each of the States and all local or other authorities within the territory of India or under the control of the Government of India.

title: What is Laws inconsistent with or in derogation of the fundamental rights?
text:
Q: What is Laws inconsistent with or in derogation of the fundamental rights?
A: All laws in force in the territory of India immediately before the commencement of this Constitution, in so far as they are inconsistent with the provisions of this Part, shall, to the extent of such inconsistency, be void. The State shall not make any law which takes away or abridges the rights conferred by this Part and any law made in contravention of this clause shall, to the extent of the contravention, be void.

title: What is Prohibition of discrimination on grounds of religion, race, caste, sex or place of birth?
text:
Q: What is Prohibition of discrimination on grounds of religion, race, caste, sex or place of birth?
A: The State shall not discriminate against any citizen on grounds only of religion, race, caste, sex, place of birth or any of them. No citizen shall, on grounds only of religion, race, caste, sex, place of birth or any of them, be subject to any disability, liability, restriction or condition with regard to access to shops, public restaurants, hotels and places of public entertainment.

title: What is Protection of certain rights regarding freedom of speech?
text:
Q: What is Protection of certain rights regarding freedom of speech?
A: All citizens shall have the right to freedom of speech and expression; to assemble peaceably and without arms; to form associations or unions; to move freely throughout the territory of India; to reside and settle in any part of the territory of India; and to practice any profession, or to carry on any occupation, trade or business.

title: What is Remedies for enforcement of rights conferred by this Part?
text:
Q: What is Remedies for enforcement of rights conferred by this Part?
A: The right to move the Supreme Court by appropriate proceedings for the enforcement of the rights conferred by this Part is guaranteed. The Supreme Court shall have power to issue directions or orders or writs, including writs in the nature of habeas corpus, mandamus, prohibition, quo warranto and certiorari, whichever may be appropriate, for the enforcement of any of the rights conferred by this Part.

text: Section 19 of the Indian Contract Act, 1872 states: When consent to agreement is caused by coercion, fraud or misrepresentation, agreement is voidable.

title: Contract Act Section 20: Agreement void where both parties under mistake (Brief)
text: Section 20 of the Indian Contract Act, 1872 states: Where both parties under mistake as to matter of fact essential to agreement, agreement is void.

title: Contract Act Section 23: Unlawful consideration or object (Brief)
text: Section 23 of the Indian Contract Act, 1872 states: Consideration or object is unlawful if forbidden by law, defeats provisions of law, is fraudulent, involves injury to person or property, or is immoral or opposed to public policy.

title: Contract Act Section 24: Agreement without consideration void (Brief)
text: Section 24 of the Indian Contract Act, 1872 states: Agreement without consideration is void unless it is in writing and registered, promise to compensate for past voluntary service, or promise to pay time-barred debt.

title: Contract Act Section 25: Exceptions to s.24 (Brief)
text: Section 25 of the Indian Contract Act, 1872 states: Agreement without consideration is void except promises made out of natural love and affection, voluntary service, or time-barred debt.

title: Contract Act Section 36: Obligations arising (Brief)
text: Section 36 of the Indian Contract Act, 1872 states: Obligations of parties to contract must be performed unless dispensed with or altered by parties or by law.

title: Contract Act Section 39: Performance by party not at fault (Brief)
text: Section 39 of the Indian Contract Act, 1872 states: When party to contract has refused to perform or disabled himself from performing promise in its entirety, promisee may put an end to contract.

title: Contract Act Section 40: Person by whom promise is to be performed (Brief)
text: Section 40 of the Indian Contract Act, 1872 states: If contract requires performance of promise by promisor, he must perform or offer to perform it himself.

title: Contract Act Section 54: Rights of joint promisee (Brief)
text: Section 54 of the Indian Contract Act, 1872 states: Where promisee accepts performance from one of several joint promisors, he cannot afterwards proceed against other joint promisors.

title: Contract Act Section 124: Contract of indemnity (Brief)
text: Section 124 of the Indian Contract Act, 1872 states: Contract by which one party promises to save other from loss caused to him by conduct of promisor or any other person.

title: Contract Act Section 126: Contract of guarantee (Brief)
text: Section 126 of the Indian Contract Act, 1872 states: Contract to perform promise or discharge liability of third person in case of his default.

title: Contract Act Section 128: Surety liability (Brief)
text: Section 128 of the Indian Contract Act, 1872 states: Liability of surety is co-extensive with that of principal debtor unless contrary appears.

title: Contract Act Section 182: Agent defined (Brief)
text: Section 182 of the Indian Contract Act, 1872 states: Agent is person employed to do any act or represent another in dealings with third person.

title: Fundamental Rights - Complete Guide (Summary)
text: The Fundamental Rights in India are enshrined in Part III (Articles 12-35) of the Constitution. These rights are essential for the development of human personality and are guaranteed by the Constitution. The six categories of fundamental rights are: 1) Right to Equality (Articles 14-18), 2) Right to Freedom (Articles 19-22), 3) Right against Exploitation (Articles 23-24), 4) Right to Freedom of Religion (Articles 25-28), 5) Cultural and Educational Rights (Articles 29-30), and 6) Right to Constitutional Remedies (Article 32). title: Article 14 - Equality Before Law (Summary)
text: Article 14 states: 'The State shall not deny to any person equality before the law or the equal protection of the laws within the territory of India.' This article ensures that all persons are equal before the law and are entitled to equal protection of laws. It prohibits discrimination on grounds of religion, race, caste, sex, or place of birth. text: Writ petitions are formal written applications to a court requesting judicial action. text: Whoever causes death by doing an act with the intention of causing death, or with the intention of causing such bodily injury as is likely to cause death, or with the knowledge that he is likely by such act to cause death, commits the offence of culpable homicide.

title: Definition of State (Brief)
text: In this Part, unless the context otherwise requires, 'the State' includes the Government and Parliament of India and the Government and the Legislature of each of the States and all local or other authorities within the territory of India or under the control of the Government of India.

title: Laws inconsistent with or in derogation of the fundamental rights (Brief)
text: All laws in force in the territory of India immediately before the commencement of this Constitution, in so far as they are inconsistent with the provisions of this Part, shall, to the extent of such inconsistency, be void.

A: Section 19 of the Indian Contract Act, 1872 states: When consent to agreement is caused by coercion, fraud or misrepresentation, agreement is voidable.

title: What is Fundamental Rights - Complete Guide? (Summary)
text: Q: What is Fundamental Rights - Complete Guide? A: The Fundamental Rights in India are enshrined in Part III (Articles 12-35) of the Constitution. These rights are essential for the development of human personality and are guaranteed by the Constitution. The six categories of fundamental rights are: 1) Right to Equality (Articles 14-18), 2) Right to Freedom (Articles 19-22), 3) Right against Exploitation (Articles 23-24), 4) Right to Freedom of Religion (Articles 25-28), 5) Cultural and Educational Rights (Articles 29-30), and 6) Right to Constitutional Remedies (Article 32). These rights can be enforced through writ petitions in the Supreme Court...

Q: What does Fundamental Rights - Complete Guide state?
A: The Fundamental Rights in India are enshrined in Part III (Articles 12-35) of the Constitution.

title: What are the provisions of Fundamental Rights - Complete Guide? (Summary)
text: Q: What are the provisions of Fundamental Rights - Complete Guide? A: The Fundamental Rights in India are enshrined in Part III (Articles 12-35) of the Constitution. These rights are essential for the development of human personality and are guaranteed by the Constitution. The six categories of fundamental rights are: 1) Right to Equality (Articles 14-18), 2) Right to Freedom (Articles 19-22), 3) Right against Exploitation (Articles 23-24), 4) Right to Freedom of Religion (Articles 25-28), 5) Cultural and Educational Rights (Articles 29-30), and 6) Right to Constitutional Remedies (Article 32). title: What is Article 14 - Equality Before Law? (Summary)
text: Q: What is Article 14 - Equality Before Law? A: Article 14 states: 'The State shall not deny to any person equality before the law or the equal protection of the laws within the territory of India.' This article ensures that all persons are equal before the law and are entitled to equal protection of laws. It prohibits discrimination on grounds of religion, race, caste, sex, or place of birth. The principle of equality is a fundamental feature of the Indian Constitution and forms the basis of democracy. The Supreme Court has interpreted this article to include the concept of...

title: What is Article 19 - Freedom of Speech and Expression? (Summary)
text: Q: What is Article 19 - Freedom of Speech and Expression? A: Article 19(1)(a) guarantees the right to freedom of speech and expression to all citizens. This includes the right to express one's views, opinions, and ideas through any medium including print, electronic, and digital media. However, this right is subject to reasonable restrictions under Article 19(2) in the interests of sovereignty and integrity of India, security of the State, friendly relations with foreign States, public order, decency or morality, contempt of court, defamation, or incitement to an offence. title: What is Article 21 - Right to Life and Personal Liberty? (Summary)
text: Q: What is Article 21 - Right to Life and Personal Liberty? A: Article 21 states: 'No person shall be deprived of his life or personal liberty except according to procedure established by law.' This article has been interpreted broadly by the Supreme Court to include the right to live with human dignity, right to livelihood, right to health, right to education, right to privacy, right to clean environment, and right to die with dignity. It forms the foundation of human rights in India and has been used to expand the scope of fundamental rights through judicial activism. The procedure...

title: What is Article 32 - Right to Constitutional Remedies? (Summary)
text: Q: What is Article 32 - Right to Constitutional Remedies? A: Article 32 provides the right to move the Supreme Court for the enforcement of fundamental rights. It is called the 'heart and soul' of the Constitution by Dr. B.R. Ambedkar. The Supreme Court can issue writs like Habeas Corpus (to produce a person), Mandamus (to command public authority), Prohibition (to prevent lower court from exceeding jurisdiction), Certiorari (to quash lower court decision), and Quo Warranto (to question authority of public office holder). This article makes fundamental rights justiciable and enforceable. It is a fundamental right itself and cannot be...

title: What is Writ Petitions - Complete Guide? (Summary)
text: Q: What is Writ Petitions - Complete Guide? A: Writ petitions are formal written applications to a court requesting judicial action. In India, five types of writs are available under Articles 32 and 226: 1) Habeas Corpus - to produce a person before the court and ensure their liberty, 2) Mandamus - to command a public authority to perform its legal duty, 3) Prohibition - to prevent a lower court from exceeding its jurisdiction, 4) Certiorari - to quash the decision of a lower court or tribunal, and 5) Quo Warranto - to question the authority of a person holding...

title: What is Article 19 - Protection of certain rights regarding freedom of speech? (Brief)
text:

A: All citizens shall have the right to freedom of speech and expression; to assemble peaceably and without arms; to form associations or unions; to move freely throughout the territory of India; to reside and settle in any part of the territory of India; and to practice any profession, or to carry on any occupation, trade or business.

title: What is Fundamental Rights in Indian Constitution? (Summary)
text: Q: What is Fundamental Rights in Indian Constitution? A: The Fundamental Rights are enshrined in Part III of the Indian Constitution (Articles 12-35). These rights are essential for the development of human personality and are guaranteed by the Constitution. The main fundamental rights include: Right to Equality (Articles 14-18), Right to Freedom (Articles 19-22), Right against Exploitation (Articles 23-24), Right to Freedom of Religion (Articles 25-28), Cultural and Educational Rights (Articles 29-30), and Right to Constitutional Remedies (Article 32). title: What is Culpable Homicide? (Brief)
text:
Q: What is Culpable Homicide?
A: Whoever causes death by doing an act with the intention of causing death, or with the intention of causing such bodily injury as is likely to cause death, or with the knowledge that he is likely by such act to cause death, commits the offence of culpable homicide.

title: What is Definition of State? (Brief)
text:
Q: What is Definition of State?
A: In this Part, unless the context otherwise requires, 'the State' includes the Government and Parliament of India and the Government and the Legislature of each of the States and all local or other authorities within the territory of India or under the control of the Government of India.

title: What is Laws inconsistent with or in derogation of the fundamental rights? (Brief)
text:
Q: What is Laws inconsistent with or in derogation of the fundamental rights?
A: All laws in force in the territory of India immediately before the commencement of this Constitution, in so far as they are inconsistent with the provisions of this Part, shall, to the extent of such inconsistency, be void.

A: All laws in force in the territory of India immediately before the commencement of this Constitution, in so far as they are inconsistent with the provisions of this Part, shall, to the extent of such inconsistency, be void.

title: What is Protection of certain rights regarding freedom of speech? (Brief)
text:
Q: What is Protection of certain rights regarding freedom of speech?
A: All citizens shall have the right to freedom of speech and expression; to assemble peaceably and without arms; to form associations or unions; to move freely throughout the territory of India; to reside and settle in any part of the territory of India; and to practice any profession, or to carry on any occupation, trade or business.

title: What is Fundamental Rights - Complete Guide? (Summary)
text: Q: What is Fundamental Rights - Complete Guide? A: The Fundamental Rights in India are enshrined in Part III (Articles 12-35) of the Constitution. These rights are essential for the development of human personality and are guaranteed by the Constitution. The six categories of fundamental rights are: 1) Right to Equality (Articles 14-18), 2) Right to Freedom (Articles 19-22), 3) Right against Exploitation (Articles 23-24), 4) Right to Freedom of Religion (Articles 25-28), 5) Cultural and Educational Rights (Articles 29-30), and 6) Right to Constitutional Remedies (Article 32). title: What is Article 14 - Equality Before Law? (Summary)
text: Q: What is Article 14 - Equality Before Law? A: Article 14 states: 'The State shall not deny to any person equality before the law or the equal protection of the laws within the territory of India.' This article ensures that all persons are equal before the law and are entitled to equal protection of laws. It prohibits discrimination on grounds of religion, race, caste, sex, or place of birth. title: What is Article 19 - Freedom of Speech and Expression? (Summary)
text: Q: What is Article 19 - Freedom of Speech and Expression? A: Article 19(1)(a) guarantees the right to freedom of speech and expression to all citizens. This includes the right to express one's views, opinions, and ideas through any medium including print, electronic, and digital media. However, this right is subject to reasonable restrictions under Article 19(2) in the interests of sovereignty and integrity of India, security of the State, friendly relations with foreign States, public order, decency or morality, contempt of court, defamation, or incitement to an offence. title: What is Article 21 - Right to Life and Personal Liberty? (Summary)
text: Q: What is Article 21 - Right to Life and Personal Liberty? A: Article 21 states: 'No person shall be deprived of his life or personal liberty except according to procedure established by law.' This article has been interpreted broadly by the Supreme Court to include the right to live with human dignity, right to livelihood, right to health, right to education, right to privacy, right to clean environment, and right to die with dignity. It forms the foundation of human rights in India and has been used to expand the scope of fundamental rights through judicial activism. The procedure...

title: What is Article 32 - Right to Constitutional Remedies? (Summary)
text: Q: What is Article 32 - Right to Constitutional Remedies? A: Article 32 provides the right to move the Supreme Court for the enforcement of fundamental rights. It is called the 'heart and soul' of the Constitution by Dr. B.R. Ambedkar. The Supreme Court can issue writs like Habeas Corpus (to produce a person), Mandamus (to command public authority), Prohibition (to prevent lower court from exceeding jurisdiction), Certiorari (to quash lower court decision), and Quo Warranto (to question authority of public office holder). This article makes fundamental rights justiciable and enforceable. It is a fundamental right itself and cannot be...

title: What is Writ Petitions - Complete Guide? (Summary)
text: Q: What is Writ Petitions - Complete Guide? A: Writ petitions are formal written applications to a court requesting judicial action. In India, five types of writs are available under Articles 32 and 226: 1) Habeas Corpus - to produce a person before the court and ensure their liberty, 2) Mandamus - to command a public authority to perform its legal duty, 3) Prohibition - to prevent a lower court from exceeding its jurisdiction, 4) Certiorari - to quash the decision of a lower court or tribunal, and 5) Quo Warranto - to question the authority of a person holding...

title: What is Protection of certain rights regarding freedom of speech? (Brief)
text:
Q: What is Protection of certain rights regarding freedom of speech?
A: All citizens shall have the right to freedom of speech and expression; to assemble peaceably and without arms; to form associations or unions; to move freely throughout the territory of India; to reside and settle in any part of the territory of India; and to practice any profession, or to carry on any occupation, trade or business.

title: What is Fundamental Rights in Indian Constitution? (Summary)
text: Q: What is Fundamental Rights in Indian Constitution? A: The Fundamental Rights are enshrined in Part III of the Indian Constitution (Articles 12-35). These rights are essential for the development of human personality and are guaranteed by the Constitution. The main fundamental rights include: Right to Equality (Articles 14-18), Right to Freedom (Articles 19-22), Right against Exploitation (Articles 23-24), Right to Freedom of Religion (Articles 25-28), Cultural and Educational Rights (Articles 29-30), and Right to Constitutional Remedies (Article 32). title: What is Culpable Homicide? (Brief)
text:
Q: What is Culpable Homicide?
A: Whoever causes death by doing an act with the intention of causing death, or with the intention of causing such bodily injury as is likely to cause death, or with the knowledge that he is likely by such act to cause death, commits the offence of culpable homicide.

title: What is Definition of State? (Brief)
text:
Q: What is Definition of State?
A: In this Part, unless the context otherwise requires, 'the State' includes the Government and Parliament of India and the Government and the Legislature of each of the States and all local or other authorities within the territory of India or under the control of the Government of India.

title: What is Laws inconsistent with or in derogation of the fundamental rights? (Brief)
text:
Q: What is Laws inconsistent with or in derogation of the fundamental rights?
A: All laws in force in the territory of India immediately before the commencement of this Constitution, in so far as they are inconsistent with the provisions of this Part, shall, to the extent of such inconsistency, be void.
